byline.contributor: Matt Apuzzo reported from Washington, and Sarah Cohen from New York.
byline.original: By MATT APUZZO and SARAH COHEN

abstract: Justice Department survey on use of force by police departments nationwide, taken in 2013, may turn out to be effectively useless due to wide variations in data kept at local level; nearly all departments said they kept track of shootings, but other data were often not tracked or were withheld; report is likely to be disappointment to those seeking to better understand police behavior in year since protests in Ferguson, Mo set off national discussion.
lead_paragraph: In a Justice Department survey, some departments said they did not know how many times their officers had used force, and some simply refused to say.

headline.main: Data on Use of Force by Police Across U.S. Proves Almost Useless
headline.print_headline: Data on Use of Force by Police Across U.S. May Prove Almost Useless
